item.title: Beocord 9000: Replacing the RAM Battery
item.description: The Beocord 9000 utilizes a 3V battery to power its 16-word memory chip, an MCM144102, which is described as a peripheral memory unit in the Motorola 6804 manual but lacks readily available detailed specifications. This chip is responsible for storing calibration data and potentially the system time, although further investigation is required. A visual representation of the circuit is included below. A positive aspect of the design is the inclusion of diode D27, which safeguards the battery against reverse polarity connection.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Replacing Capacitors
item.description: With 2017 underway and the festivities behind us, it’s time to resume the Beocord 9000 restoration. I began by replacing the electrolytic capacitors. As I’ve noted before, these Beocord 9000 units often require minimal recapping, if any. This particular unit seems to have been stored for a considerable period, and I already discovered one faulty capacitor, prompting me to replace the others. My usual practice is to use audio-grade capacitors in the signal path and opt for high-reliability, 105°C rated, long-lasting capacitors elsewhere.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Power Supply
item.description: I began troubleshooting the Beocord’s electrical issues by examining the power supply. The power supply wasn’t functioning correctly, and I wasn’t getting +24 VDC at capacitor C1. Initially, I suspected the rectifier board, so I removed it to inspect the supply capacitors (C1, C2, and C3). Here are the readings for capacitors C1 through C3. To further diagnose the problem, I swapped components from other Beocord 9000 units I had available.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Restoration of the Peak Program Meter with SMD LEDs (I)
item.description: While I’m waiting for a part for a Beocord 9000 cassette deck, I’ve started restoring another one with faulty displays. It seems cassettes are making a comeback! I’m even hoping for new tapes and maybe even a revival of the Sony Walkman II. This particular Beocord 9000 has a very dim display: [Image of dim display] The “Time Cal” bulb is also weak, a common issue. I began with the VU meter (or Peak Program Meter), as I haven’t refurbished this type before.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Finishing Up The Tape Transport
item.description: The Beocord 9000 tape transport is now fixed and reassembled. Cleaning and lubrication were done on all moving parts, including the thrust roller assembly, even though it wasn’t being replaced. The reassembly process involved reinstalling several components, starting with the take-up and supply reel assembly. Next, the clutch, interconnecting mechanics, flywheel, belts, cassette holder, and opening damper assembly were put back in place. To test the restored transport before installing it in the Beocord 9000, it was temporarily swapped into a different Beocord 9000.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Restoration of the Peak Program Meter with SMD LEDs (III)
item.description: This article, the third in a series about restoring a Beocord 9000’s peak program meters (PPM), focuses on installing and calibrating the rebuilt PPM. The initial step involved switching the original current limiting resistors with values suitable for modern SMD LEDs. These LEDs are more efficient and brighter, requiring significantly larger resistors to match the original brightness. Testing showed that 470 Ohm and 330 Ohm resistors for red and green LEDs, respectively, produced slightly brighter output compared to the original 180 Ohm and 120 Ohm resistors.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Repair of a Broken Out Leaf Spring in the Tape Mechanism
item.description: During the restoration of a Beocord 9000, a loose part was discovered within the device’s casing. This component turned out to be the left leaf spring responsible for securing the head carrier. A comparison with the corresponding right spring revealed that a small ball bearing, crucial for smooth head movement, was missing. Further investigation determined the ball bearing’s diameter to be 2.5 mm, and a readily available supply was procured. The broken plastic piece attached to the loose spring indicated that the original assembly, constantly under tension, had given way.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Opening It Up
item.description: Bang & Olufsen audio devices from the early 1980s are great to repair because their components are easily accessible for service and inspection. One of the first things to examine on Beocord 8000 through 9000 series cassette decks is the tape transport mechanism. While replacing the belts is part of regular maintenance, there are other mechanical aspects to address. Upon opening this Beocord 9000, I immediately noticed a small broken part.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Replacing the Incandescent Indicator Light Bulbs with SMD LEDs
item.description: During the restoration of a Beocord 9000, two indicator lights presented problems. One had a typical issue with a broken lead, while the other had become dim due to a deteriorating filament. To address this, I opted to use SMD LEDs as replacements, similar to a method I’ve used for Beomaster 8000 units, documented on my blog. This provides lasting stability and safeguards against potential shipping damage. However, the Beocord 9000 has more compact reflector housings compared to the Beomaster 8000, necessitating a redesign of the PCBs for the LEDs.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Total Recap - Replacement of all Electrolytic Capacitors
item.description: This article revisits a complete restoration of a Beocord 9000 cassette deck, focusing on the replacement of electrolytic capacitors for improved long-term reliability. While not as crucial as with amplifiers due to lower operating temperatures, capacitor replacement is recommended for optimal performance. The Beocord 9000, designed for serviceability, allows access to its numerous electrolytic capacitors. Unlike its predecessors, it offers easier access by removing the front and back panels instead of extracting the main circuit boards.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Restoration of the Peak Program Meter Scale Illumination
item.description: Even though the scale illumination light bulb was functioning in the Beocord 9000 display, my customer opted for a replacement to avoid any potential issues during shipping. This makes sense because these bulbs are fragile and prone to breaking, especially with rough handling. I prefer to replace all bulbs to prevent future problems. I performed this procedure before on a Beocord 9000 with a broken bulb, as documented on my blog.

item.title: Beocord 9000: The Tape Transport
item.description: After cleaning the belt residue, the tape transport needs to be removed for disassembly. Three screws and four connectors need to be detached to free the tape transport. The image shows the Beocord tape transport ready for restoration. The next stage involves taking the tape transport apart to clean, lubricate, and repair it, including replacing any worn rubber wheels.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Restoring the Peak Program Meters with SMD LEDs
item.description: I recently refurbished a Beocord 9000’s Peak Program Meter (PPM), even though it was fully functional. This decision stemmed from my success in restoring a different Beocord’s PPM that had several broken segments. Since the technology behind these PPMs is similar to that of a 7-segment display, I realized that the segments in this unit were also susceptible to future breakage. Therefore, I chose to preemptively address the issue while I had the opportunity.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Exchanging the Rubber Parts in the Tape Mechanism
item.description: My Beocord 9000 restoration project saw some good progress. I recently installed new rubber tires on the idler wheels of the tape drive mechanism to address a rewinding issue. The deck wasn’t rewinding smoothly, becoming very slow and sometimes even stopping at the end of the process. This seemed like a common problem attributed to hardened idler wheel rubber, as suggested by Beoworld.org. However, upon disassembling the mechanism, I discovered that a previous repair attempt had damaged a crucial friction pad, which was the root cause of the problem.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Repair of a Broken Out DIN-7 Jack With 3D Printed Inserts
item.description: Repairing the broken DIN 7 jack on the Beocord 9000 was simpler than anticipated. The part is identical to the one used for the Beomaster 8000’s Phono input. A 3D printed part, designed previously, was used to replace the fragile tabs on these sockets, which often break and cause the jack to fall into the panel cutout. Images of the broken jack and the 3D printed replacements are included. A short video demonstrating the installation process and the repaired plug is provided.

item.title: Beocord 9000: A Christmas Holiday Restoration Project
item.description: The holiday season provides me with the opportunity to work on extra audio restoration projects. A Beolover blog inspired this documentation of a Beocord 9000 restoration. Following this project is a Beomaster 8000, as the owner wants both devices in working order. The Beocord 9000’s exterior is in excellent condition, except for minor damage to the rosewood veneer on the left corner.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Display Restoration with SMD LEDs
item.description: The Beocord 9000 being restored has a common issue: a faulty 7-segment display. While only one segment was out, these large, early LED displays are a key design element, making repair essential. This display resembles the Beomaster 8000’s frequency display, but they are not interchangeable. The repair process, however, is the same as documented in previous posts. To begin, PCB #11 and the bezel are removed to access the display for desoldering.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Pulse Found...Beocord has life
item.description: My examination of the Beocord power system continued with the regulator and power supply boards. The regulator board houses the +5 VDC and ±15 VDC regulators, all situated on the large rear heatsink. I always inspect the heatsink compound and mica insulators for dryness, and thankfully, this Beocord appears to be in good condition. I’ve encountered instances where these components showed deterioration, but not in this case. With the regulator board cleared, I shifted focus to the power supply board’s voltages.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Ready for Bench Testing
item.description: Over the weekend, I finished the seven-segment display repair. The LEDs performed without issue during a 24-hour burn-in test. I double-checked the LEDs after reassembling the display using my specialized test equipment. My test setup has two parts for evaluating the Beocord display. The left side tests all LEDs illuminated simultaneously, while the right side allows me to test each LED channel or individual LED by adjusting jumpers. During individual LED testing, I observed some light bleed from the middle “dot” LEDs into the neighboring segments.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Seven Segment Display Board Reworked
item.description: Setting up the Beosystem display board rework station took a bit longer than anticipated, but it’s finally ready for LED display repairs and testing. A working Beocord display helped confirm the test setup’s functionality. The display board, with its front and back sides visible, now features markings indicating segment numbers and polarities. Thirty-one LEDs comprise the display. The image provides a close-up view of the original LED lights. Here, the original LED is juxtaposed with the replacement SMD LED.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Displays and Lamps
item.description: This Beocord 9000 project was on hold until new Beolover displays arrived. In the meantime, basic functionality was confirmed - the Beocord can record and play cassettes. With the displays here, the next steps are to install them, conduct thorough cassette operation tests, and share the outcome. The display work can be done without removing the Microcomputer and Display board. This image provides a top view of the display setup, highlighting the PPM scale lamp.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Restoration of the Peak Program Meter with SMD LEDs (II)
item.description: The Beocord 9000’s rebuilt Peak Program Meters (PPM) display passed a 24-hour test, confirming its functionality. To reattach the red-green covers, I secured the display to ensure a tight seal, preventing light leakage. Using a soldering iron, I melted the plastic posts of the covers, replicating the original attachment method. During cleaning, the glue holding the light guide dissolved, indicating it was likely polyvinyl ester-based. I used ‘Aleene’s Original Tacky Glue’ as a substitute, providing a clear and durable bond.

item.title: Beocord 9000: First Contact and Installing New Belts
item.description: I recently received a Beocord 9000 cassette deck that needed some care. It was shipped in its original Bang & Olufsen box, which was then placed inside a second box for protection. However, the B&O box was incorrectly oriented inside the outer box, likely resulting in an upside-down journey. The original box had some water damage: Thankfully, the Beocord 9000 itself appeared unharmed: As a rule, I never connect devices to power immediately after unpacking.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Peak Program Meter Scale Illumination with a Red/Green LED
item.description: During the restoration of a Beocord 9000 cassette deck, the light bulb illuminating the peak program meter’s dB scale malfunctioned. This common issue stems from the age of the bulbs, as their leads tend to oxidize and break under pressure. The initial state of the display, lacking illumination for the numbers on the dB scale, is shown below: The bulb is inserted into a waveguide that distributes light across the scale, with a textured surface behind the numbers for diffusion.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Replacing Capacitors Wrapped Up
item.description: The capacitor replacement on the Beocord 9000 cassette deck is complete, although it took a bit longer than anticipated. While most capacitors were within specification, a few were not, including two that had completely failed. Notably, a 220uF capacitor (C56) on the Microcomputer/Display board was the culprit behind the Beocord’s inability to power on. Another failed 220uF capacitor (C7) of the same brand was discovered on the Dolby board. This highlights the importance of checking all electrolytic capacitors in such situations.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Belt Deterioration
item.description: Replacing rubber belts is a standard restoration procedure for old audio equipment. However, Beocord 8000 and 9000 tape decks often require an extra step: cleaning up the mess left behind by deteriorated belts. Most Beocords I’ve encountered have belts degraded into a sticky, gooey substance, probably due to prolonged storage in warm conditions. Like cars, these devices suffer from lack of regular use. This picture shows the residue found in this Beocord, a common sight.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Identifying Repairs
item.description: Taking apart the tape transport allows for thorough cleaning and reveals hidden areas that require attention. While this approach makes sense for restoration, disassembling most of the transport is necessary anyway for replacing the rubber wheels. NOTE: It’s crucial to avoid disturbing the tape head assembly. It’s likely still properly aligned, or very close to it. Unless you’re certain they’re faulty, there’s no need to remove the tape heads at this stage.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Rebuilding the Pinch (Rubber) Roller
item.description: The last step in restoring my Beocord 9000 is fixing the worn-out pinch roller, a common problem in these decks given their age. These decks are over 30 years old, surpassing the lifespan of most rubber components. For optimal performance, a pinch roller rebuild is essential. Fortunately, Terry Witt of Terry’s Rubber Rollers & Wheels is an expert in restoring tape rollers. He is highly regarded in the field, as evidenced by his reputation on online forums.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Reassembly
item.description: After recapping, cleaning, and maintenance, today was the day to begin reassembling the Beocord. Starting with an empty shell, the process began. While this Bang & Olufsen model has some unique disassembly quirks, the internal components are readily accessible. The reassembly process mirrored the disassembly: the last boards removed were the first ones back in. A complete reassembly wasn’t done at this stage as the displays still needed work. Removing the transformer simplified moving and positioning the Beocord due to the reduced weight.
